newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egyptian shares at two-month low.
newsitem.headline: Egyptian shares at two-month low.

text.p: Egyptian shares fell to a two-month low on Thursday in trade plagued again by delays in the dealing and clearing systems, brokers said.

The Capital Market Authority (CMA) all-share index slipped 0.44 points to close at 232.68, its lowest level since August 19. But turnover picked up to 21.86 million pounds ($6.4 million), more than for any other day in two weeks.
Stock data on Reuter screens has been misleading since Tuesday because of unilateral changes made to the coding system at the exchange. This should be resolved by next week.
Banks joined flour mills among the most active stocks but there was no common direction in the financial sector.

National Societe Generale Bank, the first joint-venture bank to go majority foreign-owned, jumped 28.00 pounds to close at 508.00. "Investors are taking it more seriously now that Societe Generale has increased its stake," said Neveen El Tahri of Delta EAB stockbrokers.
But blue-chip Commercial International Bank fell back 20.00 to end at 440.00 pounds. "There's no good reason to explain that drop," added Tahri.

The most active flour mills were down or unchanged across the board -- Upper Egypt Flour Mills dropped 0.90 to 45.15, Central, East Delta Flour Mills by 0.50 to 35.60 and North Cairo Flour Mills by 2.00 to 107.00.
West Delta Flour Mills was unchanged at 51.00.
The CMA index for openly traded firms fell 2.02 points to 352.55 points, another one-month low, while the index for rarely traded "closed" firms rose to 162.94 from 162.88 on Wednesday.
